title: Use of a Stent in a Collapsing Exterior Ear Canal
chief_complaint: I feel like I can hear well, but people mumble. I am having progressive difficulty hearing in noisy environments.

problem_summary.onset: Progressive over the last several years.
problem_summary.course: Hearing has decreased further recently; diagnosed with polychondritis.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Difficulty in noise; no ear pain or infections reported.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Manifests in noisy and adverse listening environments; no difficulty with one-to-one communication.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to understand why hearing is difficult in noise despite feeling she hears well in quiet.

history.present_illness: Patient reports progressive hearing loss, particularly in noise. She feels people mumble.
history.otologic_history: No history of ear pain or infections.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with relapsing polychondritis, an inflammatory disease of cartilage affecting the ear, nose, and respiratory tract.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Using TDH-39 supra-aural earphones. Revealed mild to moderate-severe high-frequency conductive/mixed hearing loss. Significant air-bone gaps observed.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with PTA. Word recognition scores excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, static compliance, and middle ear pressure bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Contralateral reflexes absent at 500-4000 Hz. Ipsilateral reflexes present bilaterally (slightly elevated at 4000 Hz).

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs): Responses within normal range to 2000 Hz; present but slightly reduced at 4000 Hz.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Retest performed using ER-3A insert earphones with foam tips. Patient kept jaw open during insertion to allow deeper placement. Air-bone gaps resolved.

numeric_results.Thresholds: Within 5 dB of original bone conduction thresholds

history.present_illness: Patient returned requesting retest. Despite the explanation of the 'artifact' in the previous visit, she is still experiencing significant communication difficulties in noisy locations.
history.prior_management: Previous testing identified collapsing canals with supra-aural headphones.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Assessed with insert earphones. Hearing found to be normal except for mild high-frequency sensorineural loss at 4000 Hz and above.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Real Ear Probe Tube Microphone Measurement (REUR). Compared collapsed state vs. propped open with Lucite stent. Collapsed state showed loss of natural quarter-wavelength resonance.

numeric_results.Resonance Peak: Restored with Lucite stent (similar to normal unoccluded canal)

overall_audiologic_summary: Initial testing with supra-aural headphones showed a false conductive hearing loss (air-bone gaps) inconsistent with normal tympanometry and OAEs. Retesting with insert earphones resolved the gaps, revealing essentially normal hearing sensitivity. However, real-ear measurements confirmed that the patient's polychondritis causes the ear canals to collapse dynamically or structurally, dampening the natural high-frequency resonance of the ear canal and causing difficulty in noise.
counseling_points: Your initial hearing test showed a 'false' hearing loss because the headphones pushed your ear canals closed.
However, your difficulty hearing in noise is real. The cartilage disease (polychondritis) makes your ear canals soft, so they don't hold their shape well.
This softness causes you to lose the natural amplification of high-pitch sounds that the ear canal usually provides.
We recommend custom-made hollow 'stents' (Lucite earpieces) to physically prop your ear canals open.
These stents will restore the natural sound pathway and should help you hear better in noisy places.
We are also referring you to an otolaryngologist for management of the polychondritis.
notes_for_actor: Portray a 68-year-old woman who is pleasant but confused/frustrated.
You feel like you hear fine in quiet, one-on-one situations, but noisy places are very difficult.
When the audiologist tells you your hearing is 'normal' after the first retest, be skeptical because you know you are struggling in the real world.
Mention that you have 'polychondritis' and that your ears sometimes feel different or soft.
